page.title: 11CHANGING TIMES IN DALBEATTIE
page.content: In an interview with the grandmother of one of our pupils we learned how Dalbeattie has changed in her time. In her schooldays pupils used slate pencils and stood round an open fire. In the street in summer they went barefoot. At other times they wore clogs or went "slipshod". The roads were cobbled to help horses to take grip to pull carts and on hot days a watering cart came round to lay the dust. On winter nights the "learie" or lamplighter lit the gas lamps in the streets and threw the spent matches away for the children to scramble over. Nowadays we have computers in school as well as central heating, the roads are covered with tarmac so that cars and buses can run smoothly and safely and streets are lit up at nights by electric light.
